question.title: `Filters.eq(fieldName, value)` not actually creating `$eq` causes issues
question.body:
I'm not sure if this is a MongoDB issue, an issue with the mongo-java-driver or if I'm doing something worng.

The issue is that MongoDB can behave differently in case there is a $eq operator or if a {fieldName: value} syntax is used. See an example here: https://mongoplayground.net/p/sXKR2FvE5eg

I want to group by the groupBy field and want the type: "A" objects to be in a typeA field and vice versa for B.

I used the mongo-java-driver which does not create $eq operator in case Filter.eq is used, see documentation

For typeA I used $eq in the example and for typeB I used the non-$eq syntax. As the example demonstrates, the $eq operator actually filters correctly, but the non-$eq syntax does not.

So the question is, is this an actual MongoDB issue or should Filters.eq always created an $eq in the mongo-java-driver?

Minimal example: The following code:

var typeAPush = Accumulators.push("typeA", new Document("$cond", Arrays.asList(
        new Document("$eq", Arrays.asList("$type", "A")),
        "$$ROOT",
        "$$REMOVE"
)));
var typeBPush = Accumulators.push("typeB", new Document("$cond", Arrays.asList(
        // Using Filter.eq which does not create `$eq`
        Filters.eq("$type", "B"),
        "$$ROOT",
        "$$REMOVE"
)));
var groupStage = Aggregates.group("$groupBy",
        typeAPush,
        typeBPush
);

will produce the following Bson:

{
  "$group": {
    "_id": "$groupBy",
    "typeA": {
      "$push": {
        "$cond": [
          {
            "$eq": [
              "$type",
              "A"
            ]
          },
          "$$ROOT",
          "$$REMOVE"
        ]
      }
    },
    "typeB": {
      "$push": {
        "$cond": [
          {
            "$type": "B"
          },
          "$$ROOT",
          "$$REMOVE"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}

Note the difference of $cond between typeA and typeB. In case of typeB the condition will always be true.

answers.body:
$cond expects an aggregation expression, like { "$eq": [ "$type", "A" ] }, not a query object like { "type": "B" } which is not an expression and is treated as a literal document, which is always true, so your condition will match every document.

The solution is not use Filters.eq() from the Java driver , which produces { "field": value }, but instead use an $eq expression:

new Document("$eq", Arrays.asList("$type", "A"))

question_comments.body: Please add a minimal reproducible example in the question, not just a link. Since you are asking about Java also include the Java source and libraries&driver version.

79832579.body: "The solution is not use Filters.eq()": That is exactly my point. It is completely misleading that one should not use Filters.eq()
